title: Abiogenesis: the hypothesis that living matter can be produced from non-living matter; a term used first by T.H. Huxley in 1870. note: Brill, 2005), he has also directed (with J. Rousse-Lacordaire) a volume of collected essays entitled Etudes d’histoire de l’ésotérisme (Cerf, 2007).
title: Melanie Bayley spans the divide between the arts and sciences. She read Natural Sciences at Trinity College, Cambridge before working as a journalist for Nature. She studied English Literature at Kingston University and went on to gain a DPhil from Oxford in Victorian mathematics and literature. She is now an Honorary Fellow of Kingston University and has written on maths and fiction for the New Scientist and the New York Times. Jean-Pierre Brach is Directeur d’études at the Ecole Pratique des Hautes Etudes (Paris, Sorbonne), where he holds the Chair of ‘History of Esoteric Currents in Early Modern and Contemporary Europe’, and currently serves as a Board member of ESSWE (European Society for the Study of Western Esotericism). He is the author of La symbolique des nombres
